title: Recent homes sales in Greater Boston (Feb. 4)
author: The Boston Globe
bullets: A one-family Colonial in Andover sold for $1,849,000, offering 4,060 sq ft with 3 bedrooms and 3 baths.
A condo high-rise at 1 Dalton St., Boston, was the highest sale at $9.5 million with 3,264 sq ft.
A one-family ranch in Bellingham sold for $370,000, measuring 1,200 sq ft with 3 bedrooms and 1 bath.

title: Manhole fires on Newbury Street prompt building and street evacuations
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Six manholes exploded on Newbury Street in Boston, causing street closures and building evacuations.
The explosions, linked to an electrical issue, prompted evacuations from Gloucester Street to Dartmouth Street.
No injuries were reported, and affected streets included Newbury, Dartmouth, and Exeter on Feb. 3.

title: South Station’s new fare gates still out of service more than a week after snow storm
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: South Station's new fare gates have been out of service since a major snowstorm hit Boston over a week ago.
Between 16 and 23 inches of snow affected Boston, causing issues with the fare gates installed just a month ago.
The MBTA is working with Keolis and Scheidt & Bachmann to restore the $3.3 million fare gates at South Station.

title: Devin McCourty on ’25 Patriots: ‘A lot different than us’
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Devin McCourty praised the current Patriots for their mentality, saying they believe they can beat any opponent.
Mike Vrabel emphasized building a new program, distinct from the Patriots' past dynasties, focusing on current achievements.
Drake Maye is seen as an MVP candidate, yet some question the difficulty of the Patriots' path to Super Bowl LX.

title: Woman who posed as student at Boston high schools accepts plea deal, sentenced to probation
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Shelby Hewitt, 34, of Canton, pleaded guilty to forgery, identity fraud, and violating public conduct standards in Suffolk Superior Court.
Hewitt was sentenced to four years probation, over $9,000 in restitution, and must avoid all Boston Public Schools.
Hewitt created aliases to enroll in three Boston high schools, posing as a student during the 2022-2023 academic year.

title: BPS pauses new hiring amid deficit as district predicts hundreds of layoffs next year
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Boston Public Schools initiate a partial hiring freeze due to a $53 million budget deficit this fiscal year.
Three schools will close by 2027, potentially leading to the elimination of 300-400 educator roles.
The budget shortfall is aggravated by rising health insurance, transportation, and special education costs.

title: From SNL-style ‘Weekend Updates’ to a TD Garden beer chug, Will Campbell isn’t afraid to bring the laughs
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Patriots rookie Will Campbell performs SNL-style 'Weekend Updates' for team meetings, introducing humor to weekly film sessions.
Campbell gained fan attention after a viral beer chug at a Celtics-Heat game, showing off his comedic side.
Campbell helped stabilize the Patriots' offensive line this season despite facing challenges like injuries and tough opponents.

title: Police searching for Dorchester girl missing since Thursday
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Boston Police are searching for Mela Rosario, 17, missing from her Dorchester home since January 29.
Rosario was last seen near Brockton courthouse after her scheduled family court appearance.
She was wearing a pink jacket, black leggings, and brown Ugg boots with glasses on her last sighting.

title: Devin McCourty explains ‘travesty’ following Belichick, Kraft Hall-of-Fame snubs
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bill Belichick and Robert Kraft were not selected for the Pro Football Hall of Fame Class of 2026.
Devin McCourty criticized the Hall of Fame selection process, describing the omissions as a 'travesty.'
Kraft has been on the Hall of Fame ballot since 2013, recently advancing to the finalist stage in 2026.

title: Celtics reportedly trade Anfernee Simons to Bulls, acquire Nikola Vučević
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Celtics trade Anfernee Simons and a second-round pick to the Bulls for Nikola Vučević and a second-round pick.
Nikola Vučević, 35, averages 16.9 points and 9.0 rebounds, enhancing Boston's frontcourt while lowering salary obligations.
Trade reduces Celtics' luxury tax from $39.5 million to $17.7 million, keeping them under the NBA's tax structure first apron.
